title: File permissions
content:
Overview

File permissions focuses on read, write, execute bits and how to interpret them. This section keeps examples short and safe so you can build confidence.

Key ideas

Keep these ideas in mind as you work with File permissions:

  • Understand ownership, groups, and permission bits.
  • Make changes intentionally and verify with ls or stat.
  • Prefer safe editing and backups for critical files.

Quick start

Start with a minimal command and read the output carefully.

ls -l file.txt

Run it twice so you can see the output change when the environment changes.

Example: everyday usage

This example mirrors how you will use File permissions in daily work.

chmod u+rw file.txt

Notice the order of flags and arguments.

Example: common flags

Use flags to refine output and reduce noise.

chmod go-rwx file.txt

Always check --help if a flag is unclear.

Example: working with paths

Paths and filenames are the most common sources of mistakes.

umask

Quote paths with spaces to avoid unexpected splits.

Example: verification

Verify your work after each change to stay safe.

stat -c "%A %a" file.txt

Get comfortable confirming state before moving on.

Pitfalls to avoid

Go slowly and re-check the target when a command can change files or permissions. If you are unsure, run a read-only command first.

Practice checklist

Try the following steps in a practice folder.

  1. Inspect permissions on a few files.
  2. Change permissions on a practice file.
  3. Restore or back up a file before editing.

Real-world workflow

Combine a short command, a verification step, and a quick note about the result. This habit keeps your work reproducible.

Recap

You now have a reliable starting point for File permissions. Repeat the examples until the command patterns feel natural.
